comments.commentBody: It took Simon Pearce a long time before they set up retail outlets beyond Vermont. I suggest staying in Seattle and develop a deeper product line and then maybe go to New York or Los Angeles.

Maybe consumers are getting tired of spending money on useless trinkets.

So, one consultant thinks Glassybaby is a "concept, not a product". And just what, pray tell, is that concept? And why would consumers spend money on "concepts?" It seems the owners are very impressed with the product (and the "concept") and consumers in NYC aren't. I have a graduate degree in marketing, so I come with some "concepts" myself, but maybe in this economy lots of people have other things to do with their money and the "luxury market" is getting saturated. I say, move out of NY entirely.

In answer to the question, my immediate response is, no, this retailer cannot make it in NY. It is a hyperlocal Seattle product with no audience. Displaying piles of the same item makes it feel less precious and not worth the pricetag. Buckets of dough and time (social media is free but costly in it's way), would have to be ponied up to spread the word about it.  And the math just doesn't work. If you aim to keep your rent at 10% or even (yikes) 20% of sales (if the rent is, in fact, $9K) you'd have to sell $50k to $100k every month. That's a lot of little glasses. I'm sure the product is perfectly lovely, this is just the usual marketing conundrum.
Glassybaby must be doing something right, marketing-wise, if they got a write-up in the NYT - they've certainly reached a wider audience than they could ever hope to do with their storefront :)

My partner purchased several from the location in NYC and, although I was skeptical, I have to say once they are lined up and lit they are pretty spectacular.  The heaviness and quality when you have them in your hand are impressive...and unlike anything else I've seen.

I live a few blocks away from the Village store and when it first opened I expected it to close within a year.  Now I know it's staying open only because there's income from the stores in Seattle.  The colors are often appealing, but the store looks unprofessional (it looks like a bunch of art-school, glass-blowing students scraped together the money to rent a storefront and had nothing left over for decor or display).  I had no idea, though, that the jars cost $44 each.  That's outrageous and, though I'm sorry to say it, the store deserves to close because it's promoting the same kind of pointless, overpriced consumerism that's made everything in NYC ridiculously expensive.  It makes me mad that $44 is seen by the owner as a reasonable price for something so trivial, especially during a major recession.  I'd wish her luck, but I actually wish the store would close.

The first time I walked into Glassybaby in Seattle, the salesperson explained the 'concept' to me and I had to try very hard not to laugh. Selling just ONE thing in the whole store and for 40 bucks!

I've been scratching my head for years now trying to figure out this business.

I'm a glass artist who has been massaging, cajoling, kneading, tweaking, pummeling and generally doing whatever I can to the market (it's all concensual mind you) since 1990. If Glassbaby makes it in the City, I will first submit my blessings, then I will convert my kilns into Turkey deep fat fryers and only eat off plastic. It is an unpretty world in American Craft these days and between imports, changing tastes and the economy the battlefield is littered with fallen soldiers. I have sold my work in the City many times in the past 20 years, in a similar market, and have met with a response that was incapable of brewing a weak cup of tea. I do well in resorts, museums and smaller cities but the Big Apple has remained unripe.

The main thing to know about this business, in terms of its success here in Seattle, is that it has had phenomenal PR: a constant stream of over-the-top, gushing features in the local media. Personally, I have never gotten it. At all. The same basic object is available at Crate and Barrel for six bucks.

I bought 5 similar little glass cups from Pier One. They were recycled glass, so some measure of environmental responsibility. Best of all, they were less than $10 each. For $50 total --including buying the votives -- i was able to do a sparkling and attractive grouping on my mother's mantelpiece in her new apartment.  At Glassybaby id have been faced wih over a $200 outlay for the same effect! I admire the charitable contributions but I'm dismayed at the idea of the product (glass is heavy!) being trucked across the country. What is the carbon footprint of one of these pricey little cups? Is it really worth its cost on any level? Has the owner considered Santa Fe? Artisan friendly, healing obsessed, and wealthy. In any case , it would be fun to see the cups being blown right there in the shop. This activity alone owould generate interest. Perhaps you could accept glass for recycling in the store too, too highhlight the eco-concious nature of the process and product. I think your store as it is laid out now gives off a mass-produced vibe, which, let's face it, isnt conducive to droppping $120 bucks to score 3 little votive holders that might have come from any old factory.
Maybe offer a "heartless consumer" discount and take off the charity premium?

reading this piece, and more so the comments, has been interesting, albeit eye opening. i am an indie artist, painstakingly making my vases and bowls and votives by hand. i sell online, and in some retail stores. Mostly, I sell at craft fairs and am at brooklyn flea every weekend.

$44 for a hand-blown votive? #3, sir votive, my vases cost from $25 to $150. yes, you can buy mass-produced porcelain pieces for far less than this: they're made in china, came out by the thousands on a conveyor belt. not unique, not special, just a vase. when you buy handmade, your piece is one of a kind. it's made by a person, an artist, who's painstakingly crafted your purchase by hand. your piece has its own history.

weekly, i hear comments from buyers who are speaking to their friends in hushed tones. "$25 for a vase? is she kidding?" no, i'm not kidding. i spent hours on that vase, and it's worth far more than the effort i've put into it. imagine if the world was filled with decorative items from ikea, walmart, etc. pretty boring, no? think twice about buying home goods made in a communist factory, think about supporting your local artists. we're part of your community and you can see our dedication when you hold our work in your hands. think about who you want to profit from your purchase.

i hope this explanation has made you at least take a glimpse at the handicrafts made in your community, and compare them to the mass produced vases from target. i think you'll find their quality exceptional, as we do.

alyssaettinger.com
Please cover the Saints more. That is all.
"Let it Snow! Let it Snow! Let it Snow!
Oh man!  Baltimore just got another run at the last possible moment!  What a night of fantastic, unbelievable baseball!
Nice catch Carl.

#13 and #3, give me a break.  I see no indication that the Yankees have laid down in the past three series.  They faced TB, Boston, and TB again - and by the end of this grueling stretch they will be 3-2 against TB and 2-1 against Boston.  Who cares if they're starting call-ups or a few bench players?  They're still winning the majority of the games.

We don't consider federal tax unconstitutional though not everyone is willing to use federal highways and would prefer probably to pay for each drive or prefer to fight the fire of their house themselves. Why should the demand to participate in healthcare costs be against the law? Nobody has the right to put the burdain of unexpected needed medical help on the shoulders of others. And nobody has 100% insurance from Creator to stay healthy till his last day. Those who cannot afford even the minimal participation (for example the person whose income is below lets say 15 000 a year) have to be excused of course. But I think such people are getting medicaid, if I'm not mistaken.

Medicare for all. Great idea.

It has paid out three tomes as much as has been paid into it since it's inception.

Some of you have inferior opinions IMHO.
The Affordable Health Care Act is an abomination?
No, our lovely status quo is what is an abomination.

Commenter # 125,

I went to high school with Faron Young, who made famous the song you refer to about living fast, etc.

It sounded great when he sang that, not long out of high school. He smoked hard, drank hard, loved hard and developed emphysema. It cut short his career, and he could no longer live fast. He couldn't even climb steps without wheezing and having to rest. He got slower and sicker and slower and sicker and committed suicide years ago.

You may be young and feel like you are ten feet tall and bullet proof now, but the worst thing that you can do to yourself is destroy your health and live a hell on Earth.

Be careful what you wish for. Lots and lots of people talk the way you do when they are young enough that they know everything. Get a few years on you, and let your brain finish developing and you'll probably change your tune big time.

We have some neighbors down the street whose son has been in a nursing home since a motorcycle accident over three years now. He's a vegetable and doesn't know day from night. His diaper has to be changed often.

The people who have to pay for youthful stupidity are not always the one's like you who think the only people whose lives they screw up are their own.

"In fact, it seems far MORE wrong to force everyone to pay for the insurance of those foolish enough not to buy it, than to simply force everyone to cover their own behinds. Those are the two choices."

In my opinion, this is fallacious reasoning. I believe the Supreme Court simply needs to decide on the constitutionality of the legislation in question. Striking down important components of the new health care legislation will not doom the United State to an eternity of the current system of health care delivery. It will simply mean that our representatives need to roll up their sleeves, and work towards another solution. I will however concede that's a nearly impossible task considering the current partisan divides. You are correct in your assessment for the short term though.

I agree with many others here who argue that the only sensible solution is single payer healthcare. The unfortunate reality is that the Obama administration cooperated with Republican law makers to such a degree that the resulting legislation left everyone wanting. I'm convinced I'll see single payer healthcare become a reality within my lifetime. I hope it comes sooner rather than later.

I'm hoping Obama has learned from his failures, and will cease making such painful compromises in hopes of building a consensus. It's plainly obvious he's dealing with an entire party who value his failure above the success of the nation. The sad thing is, it may already be too late to have a chance of winning a second term in office.

So Pres. Bush could declare 2 wars without anyone's approval whatsoever, but the current president has to go to court to make a change in healthcare? Obviously something is not right with the USA govt these days.

This argument disappears with a public option or Medicade for alll. Maybe that was the republican plan all along.  Pass the billl without a public option then eviscerate the bill in court.  While the average guy can't get health coverage at a decent price.  Nice job republicans, don't get sick in America.

This is a good development for patients and the medical profession.  However, not so good for the tort lawyers.  Since the Supremes are virtually certain to find against the Obama Administration (the Constitutional law is so blindingly clear on this that even the liberal idealogues  on the Court cannot in good conscience rule otherwise).  So Obamacare is, thankfully, history.  Then, with both House and the White House under adult supervision, the tort laws are changed and the barriers to interstate competition are eliminated.  Prices drop, doctors return to their practices after having been driven out by Obamacare, sensible medical insurance subsidies for the poor are introduced and what had been the world's greatest medical care system once again stands proud.
